comment._content: Miller abandoned his cabin home, and left Washington in 1885. In 1911, the cabin was threatened by development of its rustic site. The Capital's California delegation mounted a campaign to move the structure and preserve it. It was dismantled and reconstructed in Rock Creek Park, where it was dedicated in a public ceremony on June 12, 1912. Here's Wikipedia's version of the Miller Cabin story: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquin_Miller_Cabin

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Miller died in 1913, a year after the cabin dedication ceremony (which he did not attend). His ashes were scattered near his home, "The Hights," in Oakland, California. New York Times story, May 26, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C07E1DC143FE6...
